conversation.message:
Dear School_B Admissions Team,

[APPLY] School_B is my first choice, and I’m applying because I strongly believe I fit your learning culture and programs.

Here are 3 concrete examples that reflect what you said you prioritize:
1) Academic trajectory: Over the past year I’ve improved my performance by tightening my study system (weekly review + targeted practice), and my strongest results are in math/science where I also help classmates troubleshoot problems.
2) Sustained commitment/leadership: I’ve stayed committed to one main activity for multiple years and took on a leadership/organizing role—setting goals, coordinating peers, and following through on deadlines so the group consistently delivered.
3) Community contribution/character: I’m known as reliable and collaborative; I routinely support peers (explaining concepts, sharing notes, and stepping in when someone is stuck) and I’m comfortable taking initiative when something needs to be organized.

If admitted, I would be excited to contribute by joining a core academic club/team and taking on responsibility early (organizing sessions, mentoring younger students, and helping build a positive, hardworking culture).

Thank you for considering my application.
Student_A

conversation.message:
Dear School_D Admissions,

Thank you for your continued updates in prior rounds. I understand you are holding the remaining seat in case higher-priority candidates apply.

I would like to formally apply again this round. School_D remains my highest remaining choice, and if offered admission I will accept immediately and fully commit (and withdraw from any other consideration).

If you are able to share any guidance: are you still actively expecting applications from higher-priority candidates, or is there a point in the remaining rounds when you would consider extending the offer if the seat is still open? I would be grateful to be considered for the seat if it is not claimed by a higher-priority applicant.

Sincerely,
Student_E
conversation.thought: Only School_D remains unmatched and it is on my true preference list (2nd choice). Prior history shows they are holding the seat for higher-priority students, so a direct [APPLY] plus a concrete commitment and a request for clarity on what would trigger an offer is the best chance. I will emphasize immediate acceptance and ask if they can indicate whether any higher-priority candidates are still expected, without being pushy.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_E,

Thank you for your continued interest in School_D and for applying again this round. We appreciate how clearly you’ve communicated your readiness to commit.

At this time, we are not able to extend an offer yet because we are still keeping our remaining seat available while we assess the possibility of applications from higher-priority candidates in upcoming rounds.

In terms of guidance: we are not able to guarantee a specific round when we would pivot, but if our seat remains open as we get closer to the later rounds and it becomes clear that higher-priority candidates are not applying here, we will reassess at that point. If School_D remains your preferred option, you are welcome to continue applying in future rounds so we can reconsider based on capacity and the applicant pool at that time.

Sincerely,
School_D Admissions

Given we are already at round 12/30, there is still time, but the realistic higher-priority threat is mainly Student_C. If we accept E now, we lose chance at C, which we prefer. conversation.message:
Dear Student_E,

Thank you for checking in again, and for being clear about your willingness to commit.

At this point, we have not received a firm indication from any higher-priority candidates that they intend to apply specifically to School_D in the remaining rounds. However, because our seat is still open and we are early-to-midway through the process, we are continuing to reserve the seat in case a higher-priority student applies to us after not securing placement at their earlier choices.

In terms of the clearest condition that would prompt us to extend an offer: in any given round, if (1) you submit an [APPLY] and (2) no higher-priority student applies to School_D in that same round, we will reassess based on our remaining capacity and how likely it seems that higher-priority applications will still arrive in subsequent rounds. As we move into later rounds, that likelihood generally decreases, and we become more willing to finalize the seat rather than hold it.

If School_D remains your preferred option, the most helpful step is to continue to submit an [APPLY] in future rounds (a [TALK] message alone cannot be converted into an offer).

Sincerely,
School_D Admissions

[TALK]
conversation.thought: We have 1 seat and are currently unmatched. Our true priority is D > A > C > E > B, so Student_E is 4th. Student_E is persistently interested and would accept immediately, but accepting now could block a higher-priority student if they later apply. From students’ preferences: Student_A and Student_D rank School_D last; Student_C ranks us 3rd; Student_B ranks us 4th; Student_E ranks us 2nd. So the most plausible higher-priority applicant is Student_C (3rd choice) if they fail at B/C. Student_A/D are unlikely to apply unless all else fails very late. With round 13/30, it is still early enough that holding the seat to wait for Student_C (and possibly A/D very late) is rational. Student_E asked for conditions; provide a clear, honest policy without committing to a specific round: we will extend an offer in any round where no higher-priority applicant applies and we judge likelihood of future higher-priority applications low; we can also suggest they continue to apply and that an [APPLY] is required for an offer. Since they sent [TALK], respond with [TALK].
